biases.description: Viewing situations in extreme terms without recognizing middle ground
patterns: I missed one workout so this whole week is pointless
If I can't do the full workout, why bother
I ate dessert, my diet is ruined
I can't do all 10 reps so I shouldn't even try
One bad day means I've lost all my progress
reframes: Missing one day doesn't erase your progress. One workout is better than none.
Consistency over perfection. Let's find what you CAN do today.
One meal doesn't define your nutrition. Get back on track with the next one.
Doing 6 quality reps is better than skipping entirely. Let's adjust and keep going.
Progress isn't linear. One tough day is just data, not failure.

patterns: I'll never get fit
This injury means I can never workout again
I'm too far behind to ever catch up
Everyone is judging my form
I'm going to fail at this
reframes: Fitness is a journey with ups and downs. Small steps compound over time.
Most injuries heal with proper care. Let's focus on what you CAN safely do.
Everyone starts somewhere. Comparison is the thief of joy.
Most people are focused on their own workout. You're doing great showing up.
Setbacks are part of growth. Let's break this into smaller, achievable steps.

biases.description: Measuring self-worth against others' progress or abilities
patterns: Everyone else can lift more than me
I'll never look like them
Other people make this look so easy
I'm the weakest person here
Why is everyone else progressing faster
reframes: Your only competition is who you were yesterday. Everyone has their own timeline.
Social media shows highlights, not the whole journey. Focus on YOUR progress.
What looks easy is often years of practice. Respect your own journey.
Strength is relative. You're stronger than when you started, and that's what matters.
Progress isn't always visible. Trust the process and celebrate small wins.

biases.description: Prioritizing immediate comfort over long-term goals
patterns: I'll start tomorrow
Just one more episode, then I'll workout
I'm too tired right now
I deserve a rest day (for the 5th time this week)
I'll get serious about this next month
reframes: The best time was yesterday. The second best time is now. 10 minutes is enough.
Future you will thank present you. What can you do in the next 15 minutes?
Tired is normal. Starting often creates energy. Let's do a gentle warm-up and see.
Rest is important, but consistency builds momentum. How about a light session?
There's no perfect time. Small action today beats perfect plans tomorrow.

biases.description: Feeling like you don't belong or aren't worthy of success
patterns: I don't look like someone who works out
Everyone here knows what they're doing except me
I'm just pretending to be fit
I don't deserve to be here
I'm a beginner, I shouldn't try this
reframes: Every expert was once a beginner. You belong here as much as anyone.
Asking questions and learning is strength, not weakness. Everyone started somewhere.
Your body is capable of amazing things. Give yourself credit for showing up.
You've earned your place by taking action. Keep going.
Being a beginner means you're learning. That's exactly where growth happens.

biases.description: Waiting for perfect conditions before taking action
patterns: I need the perfect gym setup before I start
I'll wait until I have more time
I need to learn everything before I begin
My form has to be perfect or I shouldn't do it
I'll start when I feel more motivated
reframes: Progress beats perfection. Start with what you have right now.
You have time for what you prioritize. Even 10 minutes counts.
Learning by doing is powerful. Start simple and build from there.
Good form develops with practice. Focus on fundamentals and improve gradually.
Motivation follows action. Start, and the energy will come.

biases.description: Believing abilities are static and cannot be developed
patterns: I'm just not athletic
I've never been flexible, I never will be
Some people are just naturally strong
I'm too old to start
I'm not built for this
reframes: Athletic ability is built, not born. Every rep is building your capacity.
Flexibility improves with consistent practice. You can change.
Strength is earned through training. Everyone can get stronger.
Age is just a number. People in their 70s build muscle. You absolutely can too.
Your body adapts to what you ask of it. Give it time and consistency.

patterns: I feel weak so I must be weak
I don't feel like it so I shouldn't do it
I feel like a failure so I am one
I feel too tired to workout
I feel like I'm not making progress
reframes: Feelings are temporary. Your strength is measured by action, not emotion.
Feelings aren't commands. Let's do 5 minutes and check in.
One feeling doesn't define you. Look at what you've actually accomplished.
Fatigue is common. Movement often creates energy. Let's try a gentle start.
Progress isn't always felt. Look at your data - you're stronger than you think.

progress_reminder.description: Show user their historical progress data

example_prompts: What would you tell a friend?

personal_progress_review.description: Compare user to their past self

micro_commitment.description: Get user to commit to smallest possible action
